Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains is $9 to Brindisi. The combined Sea and speical train fare has been reduced to $22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK samp; SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK samp; SON or other Tourist Agency.

regime solved the difficulty which their con¬tinued occupation of parts of the island might otherwise have caused by emigrating en masse to Tripoli or Asia Minor. All seemed favorable to the early consummation of the islanders’ hopes, but the Powers always prone to make a fetish of the status quo, did nothing. The Cretans passed resolutions, and Prince George but his pride in his pocket and visited one European capital after another, but all to no purpose, and on his return found sections of the population inclined to back their protests by armed revolution. It being impossible for a Prince, appointed by the great Powers to govern the island, to countenance an attempt to force the band of Europe by rioting and blooodshed, whatever his personal sympathies, □ot a little of the annoyance which would otherwise have found vent in resolutions and speeches, was kept down by his ac-tion and like confined steam, grew under pressure. Eventually the explosion came and a minority led by some able if turbulent poli¬ticians is now encamped on the mountains and engaged in skirmishes with the British and Russian troops of the International Garrison and the Cretan Police, varied by cattle lifting and the composition of appeals in particular. It is only natural that the Powers should on principle, refuse to discuss the Cretan question till order has been restored. But it is surely unthinkable that the prestige of Europe would suffer were the international forces to be with¬drawn, and their place taken by Greek troops to whom the insurgents would offer no resis¬tance. The suppression of the rebellion by the international troops would lead to much bloodshed and bitterness, would penalize the whole Cretan people for the misdeeds of a few. and would solve nothing. The islanders would remain just as anxious for union with Greece, the Powers would in a few years have to face a repetition of this summer’s disorders, and Greece would be more and more inclined to throw in her lot with the Sultan in the hope of gaining concessions in Macedonia. Neither credit nor honor are to be gained against the Cretan insurgents, and if Greece is not a strong power that is hardly a reason to neglect her appeals to be allowed to take measures for the pacification of the is¬land which she alone could carry out Prin¬ciple might well give place to expediency in Crete, and a continuance of the present policy of the Powers must lead, even if the present revolt and a score of other revolts are crushed, to bloodshed and discontent. The recent history of the island is a curious commentary on the results of European in¬tervention, and it is to be hoped that Europe will at last realise that union with Greece is the only solution that will ensure a perma¬nent settlement of the Cretan question

div.head: ITALIAN CATASTROPHE.
div.p: THREE FRESH SHOCKS.
ROYAL GENEROSITY.

COSENZA, September 13. Three fresh shocks occurred here between 8 o’clock yesterday evening and 2 o’clock this morning, causing further damage and increas- ing the panic. The Queen has given £2,000 to place the poorest of the orphans in an institute, and the King has also given £4,000 for the sufferers. x (Reuter)

div.head: THE MIKASA DISASTER
div.p: ADMIRAL TOGO SAFE

TOKIO, September 13. The Mikasa was anchored at Sasebo. The tire started at the base of the main mast and spread in the most rapid manner, exploding the magazine nearly an hour after the fire was discovered. She sank in shallow water and it is believed that she is repairable. Admiral Togo was not on board. (Reuter

div.head: GREECE AND ROUMANIA.
div.p: RUPTURE OF DIPLOMATIC-RELATIONS.

ATHENS, September 13. Diplomatic relations between Greece and Ron mania have been broken off, the latter having refused to redress various grievances regarding the Greek subjects in Roumania. (Benter)

div.head: FRANCO-GERMAN CONFERENCE.
div.p: AN AGREEMENT IMMINENT.
PARIS, September 13. The attitude of Baron de Rosen in the negotiations with M. Rouvier on the question of Morocco has been most friendly and an agreement is imminent. (Reuter)

div.head: HUNGARIAN CABINET RESIGNS !
div.p: UNIVERSAL SUFFRAGE REFUSED.
BUDAPEST, September 13. The Cabinet has resigned owing to the Emperor’s refusal to agree to universal suf¬frage. (Benter)

div.head: THE POPE AND JAPAN.
div.p: MISSION bTO THE MIKADO.
ROME, September 13. The American Bishop O’Connell has started to convey to the Mikado the Pope’s congratu¬lations upon the magnanimous peace and the treatment of Catholics by Japan. (Benter)

div.head: TYPHOID SUSPECTED.
div.p: NEW YORK, September 13. It is believed that Baron Kamnra is suffer¬ ing with typhoid fever. A specialist has been Bummoned, end bis return has been postponed indefinitely. M. Takahira remains with him. (.Benter

div.head: PEACE COMMISSIONERS SAIL.
div.p: NEW YORK, September 13. The Russian peace commissioners have sail¬ ed. Baron Kamura starts on Thursday despite iis illness. (Renter)

div.head: A BELGIAN KILLED.
div.p: LONGWY, September 13. In a demonstration of strikers a dragoon tilled an agitator of Belgian nationality. (27.)

div.head: VISIT TO LI8BON.
div.p: PARIS, September 13. M. Loubet will go to Lisbon on his way back from Spain. (Havas)

div.head: )EATH OF FRENCH POLITICIAN.
div.p: PARIS, September 13. The politician M. Goblet is dead. (Beater) M. Goblet has died. PARIS, September 13. (Hawse)

div.head: THE CAUCASUS TROUBLE.
div.p: PRINCE NAPOLEON APPOINTED GOVERNOR.
INCENDIARISM AT BAKU.

ST. PETERSBURG, September 13. Prince Napoleon has been appointed Gover¬ nor of. the Caucasus. (Haeas) BAKU, September 13. Firing continues in the outskirts and incen¬diarism and plunder are rife at-Balakhany. ST PETERSBURG, September 13. Many factories in the Volg provinces are already dosed tor want of fuel ( Renter)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: CRESCIT EUNDO—M. Avram Romano has been authorised by the Sanitary Department to practise as a pharmacist in Egypt.
STRAY AND OWNERLESS DOGS found in the Boulao district of Cairo daring to morrow night and at dawn of the 16th inst. will be poisoned by the police.

SUEZ CANAL.—10 vessels passed through the Canal on the 11th inst, 7 of which were British, 1 German, 1 French, 1 Austrian. The days receipts were frs. 330,371.94, making the total from the 1st inst frs. 3,193,305 51.

HASHISH SEIZURES —The Alexandria police seised a sack yesterday containing 21 turbas of hashish, and on Tuesday. the police of Cairo seized 31 kilogrammes of that contraband, which they found in a house in the Esbekieh quarter.

THE CAIRO AMERICAN MISSION. — The services in English in the Church of the American Mission, Cairo, will be resumed on Sunday evening next at 6 o’clock. Residents and visitors are most cordially invited to join in these-services.

A CORRECTION.—Sheikh Mohamed Shakir, Chitf of the Ulema at Alexandria, has protest¬ed in a letter published by the “Mokattam” against the statement in that paper that the relations between him and the Sheikh el Sherbine have recently been strained

LAND SALES.—We are informed that Mr. Khoury, manager of the Land and Mortgage Co. of Egypt, who recently boaght 12 feddans of land near the Mahmoudieh Canal for L E. 30,000 has resold the site for L.E. 40,000 to certain buyers, who hope to ba able to sell again at a still higher figure.

SAN STEFANO CASINO. — The farewell vocal concert will be given at the San Stefano Casino at five o’cloak this evening. On Sunday next at 10-30 a.m the-usual concert will be given-by the Bracale orchestra. A concert will also be given on Sunday afternoon from 5 to 8 p.m. by the Greek Philharmonic Band. A children’s entertainment was given yesterday afternoon in the hall of the casino, when a large number of young people attended and enjoyed immen¬sely (the representation of Cendrillon en Min¬iature^ the pupils of Professor Longhi, which demonstrated both the teaching capability of the professor and the zeal of his young pupils.

To AID THE SUFFERERS. — We are glad to learn-that in Cairo, as in Alexandria, steps are being taken to swell the funds for the relief the thousands who have suffered so terribly by the recent earthquake that devastated a great part of Calabria. A contemporary announces that the proceeds of a special performance to be given by the Italian Philodramatio Society, on the occasion of the anniversary of the entry of the royal troops into Rome, will be devoted to that -purpose and also that a performance with a similar aim will be given at the Egyptian Theatre. We again express our hope that Alex¬andrians will generously support the benefit representation at the Alhambra Theatre on Monday evening, when Come le Foglie and Meglio soli che male accompagnati will be, staged by the Delia Gaarda Dramatio Company.

THE WEATHER IN CAIRO. — A most wel¬come change in the weather has taken place in Cairo during tbd'pastfo# days. “The heat, which was so intense, and at times almost unbearable, during Julyr and1 August, has considerably diminished, and the" morn-ings and ‘evenings now are delightful: Resi¬dents who have been obliged to pass the sum¬mer in that city will have just cause to remember it, far the summer-now coming to a dose has been one of the hottest and most trying on record, the thermometer in several instances having been up as high as 114° Fahrenheit in the shade between noon and 8 o’clock, vlt has now fallen to 90° Fahrenheit >t the hottest time of the day, but at night the temperature is no more than ; 60° Fatten heit.

div.head: IRRIGATION.
div.p: TRANSFORMATION. PROGRESSES

The Project*Circle of the Irrigation Depart- msnt has almost computed its transformation'! of the “basin” system to that of pen irrigation in Beni Suef province. The officials | of this circle will next year remodel the irrigation tian system of Gizeh province and by 1907 the whole of Upper Egypt frill enjoy the benefits of perennial irrigation. In Lower Egypt-the -system of perennial irrigation's supreme-except in a few limited area and in these the remodeling will not take more than twelve months to complete. In three years' time, therefor* Egypt will pos¬sess a complete system of perennial irrigation, to the great advantage of landowners and of the country in general.
THB TELEPHONE COMPANY

The State Telegraph Department are about to any for the company two new cites lines between Cairo and Alexandria which, when completed next year, will greatly relieve the present pressure on the two lines that have been now in use for three years. There will also be -another line between Cairo and Tantah, and Alexandria and the latter- place so that in future messages can be transmitted | direct between the two cities and Tantah. Part of the work on-this line has been finished, and the remainder will be completed as soon as the necessary grant has been obtained by the Telegraph Department We are informed that, should the new service to Tantah prove a commercial success there is every probability that the system will be extended to important towns, such as Zagazig, Por Mansourah, and, perhaps, Suez.
THB HELOUAN RAILWAY.

As we mentioned a short time ago, it has been decided to double the line between Bab-el-Louk and TouraL The engineers of the company are at present busily engaged ba the work, and the laying of the second line of rails will be taken in hand early in the new year, when the neceesary material twill have arrived. Four new first-date-Car- riages on the corridor system, and similar to those in use on the State Railways are ex- pected from Europe in November. It is also (intended to improve all the stations on the line. There is no truth in the rumour that the Heltuan Railway has lately purchased a large plot of land at El Maadi, one of the |lstations, with the intention of re-selling it in small plots for building purposes.
THB LATE MOG PASHA.

The funeral service for tire late Mog Pasha took place at 9 a.m. morning at St. Caffcerine’s CathedraL Among those present were H. E. Ali Bey Sadik, Sub-Governor of Alexandria, re¬presenting the Regent with the Consuls and several representatives of the Caisse de la Dette. The family of the late Mog Pasha tenders its thanks to those' Who were present at the funeral service this morning, to those who sent | wreath* and to all who have .shown their sympathy on the sad occasion.

div.head: CIGARETTE -TRADE OF EGYPT
div.p: As most of our resident readers are aware the cigarette trade is one of the most important and flourishing industries in this country, and it bar been remarkably developed daring the last few years? The export portion of the trade is the one that has been more steadily Increas¬ing in volume and, judging by the customs return* the^increase has lately been augment-ing by leaps and bounds. Last year the total experts amounted approximately to 500 mil¬lion cigarette# weighing over 650 tons, whilst the previous year’s total of the cigarettes exported from Alexandria, Port Said, and Suez was about 400 million* so that there was an increase of one year of no less 100 millions. As shown by these customs return* during the past quinquennial period the business of the 4Sr leading firms of manufacturers has increas- considerably, and compared with, say fifteen or twenty yean ago, there Law beer an enor- mous development in the which cigarette trade and a consequent augmentation in the number of all manufacturers. Of the total-exports one Cairo firm alone exported 134 million cigarette* the whole of which went to Germany and was of the cheaper description. Another well-known Cairo firm comes next with art ex- port of 110 million* a large portion of which went to the United Kingdomand was oomposed mostly of the dearer and better class of c;ga- rettes. '‘Almost the whole manufacturing trade is done in Cairo on account of the dryness of the dimate and its consequent suitability From the returns that have been furnished by the customs of that city the exports during the past four years have been as follows7 in round THB HELOUAN RAILWAY. As we mentioned a short time ago, it has been decided to double the line between Bab-el-Louk and TouraL The engineers of the company are at present busily engaged ba the work, and the laying of the second line of rails will be taken in hand early in the new year, when the neceesary material twill have arrived. Four new first-date-Car- riages on the corridor system, and similar to those in use on the State Railways are ex- pected from Europe in November. It is also (intended to improve all the stations on the line. There is no truth in the rumour that the Heltuan Railway has lately purchased a large plot of land at El Maadi, one of the |lstations, with the intention of re-selling it in small plots for building purposes. figures Cigarettes. Weight in kilos.many took about one half, whilst the United Kingdom comes next with dose on 100,000 kilos, valued at £80,000. In there last figures we do not include the quantities exported to British possessions or oolonie*whioh latter took 75,500 kilos, worth £59,700. As we mentioned in an article published a few days ago the exports to the United States of America oom- pared with that of other countries are very small on account of the vexationx restrictions imposed by the American Custdifc#» ’ Oat of the total export trade from Egypt of 620 metric tons, Fort Said stands at the head of the ports of embarkation. It exported some 307 ton* valued at L.E. 246.000 ; Alexandria exported some 224 ton* of a value of L.E. 180,000 and Suez about 88 tons valued at LE 69,000. Of the 607 tons from Pott Said, 42 tons went to the United KingdCin,v 194 tons to Germany, and 11 to the Far East. Th^ average wholesale export prioe of Egyptian* cigarettes appears to be atnnt 7s. 61 or 9.50 franos per lb. The manufacturers complain that their trade suffers at present under a great disadvantage, in that they have to pay an import duty of P.T. 20, on every kilogramme imported, and receive a drawback on exports of half the amount, which they consider unjust as finder the customs tariff now in force they have to pay the same amount of duty on cigarettes,! whether they are consumed in the county or ont of it. They therefore contend that the cigarett a manufactured expressly for exporta- tion should be exempt of duty altogsther, and offered some time ago W erect bonded ware1- houses for the manufacture of the goods intend- ed for export in bond. So far the Customs authorities have not entertained, or rather given their consent to this arrangement, but should they at any future time sanction wonld give a farther great stimulus to the cigarette industry of Egypt, and Cairo in par¬ticular. We may remark, en passantt that the design¬ation of the cigarettes made in this oorfhtiy' ’as Egyptian is a misnomer, as the tobacco comes almost entirely from Turkey, as most people are aware, and the paper used in rolling the cigarettes is imported from Austria principally. A small quantity of the tobacco Comes from the district of Xauthfy in tire-province of Thrace ; and the export is almost entirely from Cavalla, where the leading manufacturers of Cairo and Alexandria possess large depth containing, at times, many thousands the ciga¬rettes being now exported to every civilised part of the globe—from Norway to Cape Colony f bales, from Japan to the West Coast of Africa, and to ^Cvery country on the continent of America as well. Besides a huge local and export trade, some of the leading firms supply as well the tobacco regies of France, Italy, and Austria.

div.head: UNE MOSQUEE A PARIS
div.p: Les demarches d’un Egyptien

Un Francis 6tabli an Cairo depuia de nom brouses anuses, M. L. Lambert, a pris l’initia- tive de feire demarches aar demarches poor fairo aboutir le projet de la creation d’une moaqude k Paris. A on journaliate qui eat alld le voir M. Lam bert a fait, aveo beanooap d’amabilita, les ds olarationa suivantes: — Je 8oia vena expr8 k Paris poor aoa mettre an gouvemement fran^aia oette inures aante question, dont lea consequences politi ques seront enormes. J’ai eu une longue conference hier aveo on bant fonotionnairo do ministfcre des oultes, qui a fait le meilleur acoueil k mon projet et ma oonaeilie de m’adresser au miniatro dee affaires £trangsres pour quo oeiui-ci entamat des negooiations aveo la direction des domaines afin de trouver k Paris un terrain oonvenable dont la concession nous permettrait d’edifier la moaqude taut dsirde. Il y a quelques jours je m’etais Igalemeut rendu au minUtro de l’interieur qui a tranamis depuia le dossier oontenant vingt un documents rolatifs k oette demande de concession. Ces documents sont aignds par les quatre grands cheikba de 1’University d’El-Arhar, c’eat-k-dire par les personnages lea plus influ¬ents du monde musulman. L’an d’eax, Abd-el-Rahman-el-Maleky (Maro- oain), qui eat trss influent non seulement en Egypte, maia en Alg6rie et aurtout au Maroc, son pays d’origine, oil je vais me renoontrer avec lui dans quelques joare et lui fairo part du rsultat qu’auront donnd mes demarches, et qui sera aocompagn^ par son neveu, le fils d’Abd-el-Kader, approndrait aveo une joie sincere que la France a aooaeilli favorablement notre requete. Le oheikh Abd-el-Rahman-el-Maleky m’avait manifesto le dsir de venir k Paris pour m’aa aiater dans mes demarches, et oela aurait trsa oertainement 4t4 du meilleur effet, mais au dernier moment il n’a pu aooomplir ce voyage. Mais j’eapdre que le gouvemement frangai ne voudra pas tarder plus longtemps k prondro une decision, puisque depuis de nombrouses I ann^es des mosqudes ont 6t6 4difi6es k Londrea et k Berlin par lea soins des gouvemements | anglais et allemand. Le prestige de la France aurait tout k gagner I k pareille decision: l’abandon de l’Egypte k [’Angleterre a cr6y obez les musulmans un | cbeux ytat d’esprit k notre dgard. Vo ilk quarante-trois ans que j’habite le Cairo, I j’avais accompagnd M. de Lesseps; j’ai do aombreuses relations en Egypte, et tous les musulmans avec lesquels j’ai eu l’oooasion de n’entrotenir m’ont toujours dit: Comment so ait-il que la France, pays bospitalier et g4n6 ' reux, ne fasse rien pour nous 1 Eh bien I le moment est venu, les fonds n6 ceaaairoa k l’yreotion d’une mosqu6e k Paris et aussi k Marseille — oh se trouvent de nom breux musulmans — sont prdts. De divers cdtds j’ai re$u en effet des offres de oonoours gyndreux et j'ai pu fairo parvenir au miniature de l’intyriear les listes de soascription, dont le nombre s’augmente cheque jour. Le sultan de Tutquie, le Khydive d’Egypte et plusieurs princes, princesses, paches et riches musulmans ne manqueront paa de participer k oette oeuvre, jen suis con vain on. Les chefs roligieux de l’lslam n’ont paa mar ohandy, en plus d’une oiroonstanoe, les nom breuses concessions de terrains aooord4es aux oongrygations religieuaes, et la France en a obtenu une large part. (Test bien le moins que le dysir legitime dea musulmans soit pris en considyration. Nous avons tout k gagner, oar l’Allemagne nous sup- plan te chaque jour davantage dans l’influence que nous avons tonjoars possydye auprks des disciples de Mahomet, qui oependant nous ai ment toujours. Je vais fairo dresser les plans de la future mosquye, qui ne sera autre chose qu’un oara- vansyrail comprenant one yoole et une salle do union. — Oh s’yihvera oette mosquye t — Probablement prks des Invalides ; mais d’ici pen j’espkre £tre flxy k oet ygard. Boyer persuady que, le jour oh Paris aara sa mosquye, les musulmans y viendront volontiers et en grand nombre: ils a’y sentiront mieux ohtz eux.

div.head: Tribunal Oonsulaire d’Italie
div.p: Le tribunal oonsulaire d’Italie a condamny le oonstable Alessandrello, anoien agent de la police secrkte da kism de la place, k un an e demi de delusion poor avoir biesay d’un coup de revolver un italien dans nn cabaret de U rue des amors. Le tribunal a condamny le frkre du SUB nom my Giuseppe Alessandrello k 79 jours de prison et Grimaldi qui a donnd l’hospitality k Alessandrello k 25 jours de la m4me peine.

div.head: SUDAN LAND SETTLEMENT.
div.p: NEW ORDINANCE.

Whereas it is expedient to make special pro- vision for the settlement of claims to waste forest and unoccupied lands, It is hereby enacted as follows :— 1—This Ordinance may be called “The Land Settlement Ordinance, 1905." 2. —In this Ordinance the word “land" in-cludes benefits to arise out of land and things attached to the earth or permanently fastened to anything attached to the earth. The words "unoccupied land" include uncul- tivated land and all land which shall not have been in the uninterrupted occupation of some person or persons for a period exceeding five years next before a notice given by the Go¬vernor General with reference to such lands under the next section, and also all lands which, owing to their height above the river, the infrequency of rains, and other circum- stancee, have been cultivated at irregular in¬tervals only. 3. —(i.) Whenever it shall appear expedient to the Governor General to effect a settlement of claims in or over any lands whioh are or are alleged to be waste, forest, or unoccupied, he shall publish a notice in the "Sudan Qszatte," (а) specifying as nearly as possible the situation and limits of such land. (б) declaring it is proposed to effect a settle¬ment of such land. (,•) appointing an Officer (hereinafter called the Settlement Officer) to inquire into and determine the existence nature and rights claimed by or alleged to exist in favor of any person in or over any land comprised within such limits and to deal with the same as provided in this Ordinanoe. (ii.) The Governor General may at any time by a notice in the ‘ Sudan Gazatte” annul the appointment of any Settlement Officer or appoint another Officer in his place. 4. —When a notice has been published under section 3 the Settlement Offioer shall publish in Arabic at the offices of the Governor of the Province and the Mamur of the district and at convenient places in the neighbourhood of such land a proclamation. (а) specifying as nearly as possible the situation and limits of the land which it is proposed to settle. (б) fixing a period within which any pereon claiming any right in or over snch land is required to present to such Officer a written notice specifying the nature of such olaim. 5. —(i) After the expiration of the period specified in section 4 the Settlement Officer shall hold enquiries at convenient places on or near the land which it is proposed to settle. 8uch reasonable notice as may be possible ot the date and place of such enquiries shall be given to the claimants. The Settlement Officer shall enquire into all claims made under section 4 and the existance of any right or practice in or over the land in respect of which no claim has been made and shall record a summary of his enquiry in writing. (ii.) And after hearing the claimants or their dnly authorised agents if they present themselves the Settlement Officer shall ad¬judicate upon every claim. 6. —(i.) If the Settlement Officer is satisfied that any person is entitled to the beneficial ownership of any land he shall make an order admitting such ownership. (ii) If the Settlement Offioer is satisfied, as regards any land, that it is entirely free from any private rights or that the rights existing in or over it do not amount to fall ownership he shall make an order that the ownership of I the land is in the Government (iii.) If the Settlement Officer is satisfied that any person is entitled to any rights of the kind mentioned hereinafter in or over any land owned by the Government or any other person, or that the Government is entitled to any suoh right of a private nature in or over land owned by any person, that is to say (a) a right to cultivate by the natural flood of the river or by rain, (5) a right of pasture, (c) a right to forest produce, (f) any other beneficial rights or practice, the Settlement Officer shall make an order admitting the rights and defining the (iv.) The Settlement Offioer may, but it shall not be necessary for him, to reoord (a) a right of way. (A) a right to a watercourse or to the use of water. (v.) Where a claim to any right is admitted the Settlement Officer shall record the local limits within which such right may be ed the extent to which the benefit thereof may be leased sold or bartered and such other particulars as may be necessary to define the nature incidents and extent of the right. 7. —In adjudicating upon claims to land the following roles shall be followed : — (i.) The rules laid down for land commis¬sions by the Title of Lands Ordinances shall be followed by the Settlement Officer, so far as they are not inconsistent with this Ordinance ; provided that a claimant shall not be barred under section 10 of the Title ofLand Ordinary 1899 on account of his not having presented a claim under that Ordinance, if he has during the five years preceding the presentation of his claim to the Settlement Officer exercised u of right any beneficial right in or over the land in question. (ii.) AU waste forest and unoccupied land shall be deemed to be the property of the Government until the contrary be proved. (iii.) In the oase of land which under the custemary methods in use with regard to the same is cultivable at irregular intervals, the fact that a person has cultivated the same for whatever period shall not by itself give him the absolute ownership of the land. (iv.) The exercise by any person of rights in or over one or more portions or panels of tad shall not be taken as a presumption In his and nothing is at present known whioh should make the yield smaller than the last Europe during the past season has bought far less Surat than daring the preoeding season, bnt the Indian and Japanese mills have been busy. Tbe Indian holders of ootton have followed the Amerioan policy of refusing low prioes and have oarried over an unusually heavy stock into the new season. It remains to be seen bow far suoh a policy will answer their purpose. From Egypt tbe reports are distinctly good. Thera is saffioitnt water for the cultivator, although the volume of water fa the Nile has been only moderately full. A large acreage has been planted, and prospeots are at present flattering. Tbe crop bos yet to fear autumn fogs, bnt if it escape these, or unless they are unusually injurious, a lull or large crop is to be looked for. It mould therefore appear that at the present moment the prospeots of all the principal crops an of a nature to encourage hopes of oootinned abundanoe. Even if the American orop should prove disappointing tbe large surplus earned over from the late orop will avert any real danger of shortage. Crops and surpluses to¬gether ought to supply every requirement of the spindles of the world for 1905-6. Appear¬ances, therefore, are in favor of another year’s healthy trade, and it can only be hoped that as the season pisses it may prove as good and as profitable for Lancashire as the season 1904-5. in Bogtieh will be resumed fa the Church of tbe American Mission Cairo, on the evening of the 17th of theonrrent month. The hour of service is from 6 p.m. to 7. Residents and visitors are cordially invited to attend. The Church is a part of the Missiom pre¬mises, boated almost fa front of Shepheard's Hotel. 26422-8-1

favor as against the Government of ownership of any rights in or over any greater extent of land than that in or over which such rights were exercised. 8. —All rights admitted by the Settlement Officer and recorded in his order shall be pre¬sumed to be in gross and inheritable unless it is otherwise stated in the order. 9. —No right in or over any land whioh might have been made tho subject of a claim under this Ordinance other than a right of way or to a watercourse or the use of water shall be enforceable otherwise than in accordance with the provisions of this Ordinance. 10 In an enquiry under this Ordinance the Settlement Officer shall have the same powers as to summoning witnesses, and compelling their attendance, and administering oaths,and as to all matters of procedure as a Court under the Civil Justice Ordinance, and the proce¬dure directed to be observed by Civil Courts shall be followed so far as applicable. EXPROPRIATION OF RIGHTS. 11. —Whenever a scheme or a provisional scheme has been approved for the artificial irrigation of any land which has been or may be declared to be Government tad under this Ordinance or such land is needed for building or for a public purpose the Governor General may compulsorily expropriate all private rights, if any, existing in or over such land. 12. —Whenever the Governor General has determined to make use if the powers con¬ferred by the last section in respect of any particular land, a notice signed by him, con¬taining a declaration to that effect, shall be published in the “Sudan Gazette.” Such notice may ba added to the notice published under section 3 or may be a separate notice. It shall bo conclusive evidence that the land is needed for a purpose authorised by this Ordinance. 13. —The Settlement Officer shall thereupon proceed to expropriate all rights existing in or over such land in manner provided by the Land Acquisition Ordinance 1903 as hereinafter varied. 14. —For the purpose of such expropria- >n (i.) The Settlement Officer shall be deemed to be a Governor proceeding under the Land Acquisition Ordinance 1903. (ii.) The claimant shall be deemed to be person interested and appearing before him pursuance of a notice given under section 7 of that Aot, and the provisions of the preceding sections shall be deemed to have been complied with. (iii.) In the event of the Settlement Officer failing to come to a friendly agreement with the persons interested under section 9 the matter shall be settled by him as sole arbi¬trator and for that purpose he shall have the powers of and be subject to the like provisions as a Commission of Arbitration appointed under Section 12 of the Land Ac¬quisition Ordinance 1903. (iv.) The Settlement Officer may award compensation in land or partly in land and partly in money. (v.) If the compensation consists of tad and the Government shall not be ready to give delivery of the some to the persons interested simultaneously with the taking over by the Government of rights expropriated from them the Settlement Officer shall award compensation by way of rent from the date when the Government enters into possession of such rights to the date when the Govern¬ment delivers the tad or notifies its willing- ness to do so. (vi.) In determining the amount of com¬pensation for rights which have no market value or of which the market value does not represent the full value to the person in¬terested the arbitrator shall take into con-sideration in addition to the other matters mentioned in section 17 of the Land Acqui- tion Ordinance the profit derivable by the persons interested from the exercise of such rights. If the arbitrator shall award compen-sation in land the land shall be of such area and so selected that it shall be as profita¬ble to the person interested as the right ex¬propriated from him. (vit) If upon the expropriation of rights over “karn” or “bugr" tads artificially irri¬gated tad is awarded by way of compensation the tad so awarded shall not he less in area than one tenth of the “karn” or “bngr" tads over which such expropriated rights extend. Provided that upon the recommendation of the Settlement Officer the Governor General may dispense with this rule in particular t where such compensation would he in the opinion of the Settlement Officer undoubtedly APPEALS. 15.—(t) An appeal shall lie from any order made by a Settlement Officer under section 6 or 14 of this Ordinance to such civil judge or magistrate of the first class as the Governor General may appoint to hear appeals from such orders. (it) Bvery appeal under the last foregoing section must be presented within six months of the order. It shall be made by petition fa writing and may be delivered to the Settle¬ment Officer who shall forward it without delay to the Officer competent to hear the same. (iii.) Every such appeal shall be heard in the manner prescribed for the hearing of appeals by the Court ot the Mudir order the Civil Justice Ordinance and the same fees shall be payable in respect thereof as on an appeal to the Court of the Mudir under that Ordi¬nance and the order passed on such appeal shall be final RESTRAINT ON ALIENATION. 16.—Any rights over land declared to be Government land under this Ordinance and any tad granted by way of compensation under this Ordinance shall not ha A, mortgaged or charged except with the consent of the Governor of the Province and any alienation mortage charge or attempt to

alienate mortgage or charge without such consent shall be void. Such consent shall not however be required to a lease of such rights or tad for a period n t exceeding three years or to their demise by will. RIGHTS np WAT AND WATERCOURSE. ’.—A Settlement Offioer may from time to time with the previous oonsent of the Gover- of the Provinoe stop any public or private way nr watercourse. Provided that for the way or watercourse so stopped another way or watercourse which in the opinion of the Governor is equally conve¬nient already exists or has been provided or constructed by the Settlement Officer.

div.head: ISLAND OF CYPRUS.
div.p: LIMASOL AND PAPHOS.

(FROM A CORRISPOMDINT.) We now tarn to the southern part of the island of Cyprus which is that nearest of access to Egypt, and the part which was is contact with civilisation from earliest times. The whole of the southern coast, as would be expected, is relaxing, more so even than Beyront and the plain of Sharon as far as 1 could judge, and the British military and civilians stationed at Limasol and Larnaca are not, I think, to be envied.lt is also a doubtful question as to what will be the effect upon these two ports of call of the new railway and the opening of the harbour of Famagusta. The Larnaca and Limasol ►eamship company is, I hear, making prepara¬tions to look after their interests. But it is diffioult to see how larnaca will survive, save as the telegraph station for the oapital, if its trade is largely diverted. The plaoe however can boast of great antiquity, as under tbe ancient name of Cftion it was probably one of the oldest Phoeniota settlements in the Medi-terranean, and is thought to he the Chittim of Numbers XXIV v. 24 and elsewhere. The roads from Nicosia to larnaca and to Limasol are of no particular interest, as they simply cross some bare foothills, the soil being of a chalky nature all over the low range to the southeast of the island. Bat some prettier scenery is met with about halfway between Nioosia and Limasol, where a oonple of midday rest houses are to be found, dose to two successive mountain torrents. And the road is lined the rest of the way with groves of carob trees until the very sight of thrm hcomee monotony itself. There are plenty of vines higher on the hills, but save for some groves of very ancient fig and oiive trees near the sites of ancient towns and settlements, long since abandoned, the drive of 54 miles is disappointing. Moreover in summer the roads in Cypres everywhere full of white dost, save on the Troodos, so that a landau is the only suitable oon- ia-oe. terestiog excursions. With the ancient Phoe¬nician Amattins on the seashore seven miles to the East and the Argive city of Carium two miles to the west, there would be plenty for the antiquarian to discover had not Signor di Ceenola, the Amerioan Consul, dug only too suooessfolly in the latter, and the French removed from the former a oolossai stone vase and other trea¬sures now in the Louvre. But coming down to crosadirg times the Englishman will like the hole, now converted into a native fa which Riohard I. married Queen Berongaxia. This site is in Limasol itself, while about seven miles off the road to Paphos, north of the salt lake and pro¬montory beyond, lies the remains of the tower of Colossi, where the King and Queen spent their honeymoon. The castle tower lies in a jsplendid situation with a magnificent view from the roof. The place is kept by an Englishman, who, with his wife, is very hospi¬table to stangera. The arms containing the British lions, the Jerusalem cross, and the flour de lys are still visible on the eastern wall. Paphos is about 48 miles distent from Limisol by a hilly road with many zigzags np and down the pees, as yon arose ths nu¬merous valleys with their mountain torrents that oome down from Troodos. No Bible student and admirer of Paul and Barnabas would wish to miss those secluded spots which have such a history to tell There is a Palaoe-Paphos and a Neo Paphos, and they are distant ten miles the one from the other. The former was the great centre of Aphrodite worship, and the surf of the coast below still breaks into foam in fan- tastio shapes. The ancient temple lies perched upon a cliff now about two-thirds of a mile from the shore. And hither came that fastful throng year by year from many tads to do node worship to the goddess. Doubtless this is what cansed Neo-Paphos with its tiny harbom to become the site of apro-oonsnlate fa apostolio times. But now, save for the commissioner’s yacht and a few small fishing craft with the remains of a mediicval castle as a break¬water to the bay, nothing except masses of stores and here and there a Corinthian pillar remains to mark the scene where Sergius Paulus was converted to the Christian faith. They show the visitor two pillars place to a Byzantine church where they say St Paul was i beaten. But it is possible from tradition to - complete the story. For we are told that the statue of the goddess was overthrown by the prayers of Barnabas. And there seems no ' room for doubting that it was the work of this apostle that led to the overthrow of this hideous form of worship. Now, perhaps, we see ’ why he was so anxious to return to bis native He felt he had a work

div.head: THE COMING COTTON SEASON
div.p: Forecasts of the new season an seldom more difficult than when the crops are specially sub¬ject to the influence of the weather far some time to come. Nevertheless it is possible to sketch the broad features and probabilities of the new season on what is already known of the old. Moreover, fa one respect at least, the new ' i less uncertain than any ofitsim- predetoaeon. Spinners are already supplied with orders for months forward, and they are covered by contents for cotton. A period of good business—longer or shorter—is thus assured. Nor is any reason yet apparent which should prevent the giving of farther orders sa the old contracts expire. Harvests generally have been goofl fa most parts of the worrid, the chances of Improvement fa basinets now that peace is declared good, and from none of the large foreign markets need less than an average or fall demand be looked for. Thereis likely to be more rather than less activity in the home trade, and Lancashire is pnttiog up Dew mills to meet the demand from all quarters. When all of them are fully at work the actual consumption may rise to 60,000 Amerioan bales a week instead of of 65,000 to 56,000 estimated for the past twelve months. If these views may be partly modified by the knowledge that large stocks of goods are now held fa some of the Eastern may nevertheless prove broadly prioes this year—namely, a good business, the holding back of ootton by planters, sod specu¬lative activity. Only the development of tbe season’s business and the fortunes of the crop can decide theoorreot Unless cotton be too dear and prices in Manchester consequently too high, a fall business with the world is likely to be done, end in this sense — namely, fa a reasonable security for a good season’s demand the entry into the new season shows lees uncertainty then naual. On the question of the price of cotton, the position at the present moment is less easy to define. The crop has to face the risk of heat (although the period of great heat is now be nearly over) and frost Information about the orop has been so much affected by the pro¬paganda of speculators and by the Bureau irregularities that its actual position is more obscure than usual. Broadly, it may be said that if the Barcau be trusted the crop mast be small, and that if the general reports received ■imaesol, however, is a centre of many in- ky merchants .ffpm their correspondents be question, bnt on tbe whob the probabilities wonld seem to point to a bwer range of prioes for 1905-6. It is also not improbable that the oomfag season may show rather large fluctuations. The new orop is ooming down to the ports, where largo supplies exist, and it has to he shipped to Europe, where stooks of some magnitude are in the hands of merohants and spinners. These oiroumstanoea may possibly prodnoe a tempo¬rary depression of a notable kind, but it most in that case be dearly remembered that any decline going below the onltivator’s oostof growing ootton, should thsrt occur, carries with it the certainty of redooed acreage and careless cultivation of the following orop and of a consequent rebound. Appearances point to Lancashire’s oonsnmption being somewhat larger this season than last, but the takings will not be so large. The shipments to Great Britain, whioh have been ronndly 4,100,000 fa the past season, may not be so large during that opon whioh we are now entering, but the Liverpool stock is likely to be larger and may even reaoh considerable figures. U is also quite possible that the new season may at some time show a long period of small spot markets whenever the spinner falls hack on his reserve stooks of ootton. With regard to tbe Indian orop it ia at pres¬ent impossible to say much. The prospeots are enoouragfag in those districts whioh grow the principal varieties of ootton. Shortage of rain¬fall has been reported fa the Punjaub and fa Rsjputaoa, but these districts, although they grow some Bengal ootton, are principally known for their wheat production. Elsewhere the reins have bean sufficient or plentiful, and fa Gujarat exoMsive. The tat Indian crop was lugfa tfceaoreerfthe pemt owp h tamMd, and nothing is at present known whioh should make the yield smaller than the last Europe during the past season has bought far less Surat than daring the preoeding season, bnt the Indian and Japanese mills have been busy. Tbe Indian holders of ootton have followed the Amerioan policy of refusing low prioes and have oarried over an unusually heavy stock into the new season. It remains to be seen bow far suoh a policy will answer their purpose. From Egypt tbe reports are distinctly good. Thera is saffioitnt water for the cultivator, although the volume of water fa the Nile has been only moderately full. A large acreage has been planted, and prospeots are at present flattering. Tbe crop bos yet to fear autumn fogs, bnt if it escape these, or unless they are unusually injurious, a lull or large crop is to be looked for. It mould therefore appear that at the present moment the prospeots of all the principal crops an of a nature to encourage hopes of oootinned abundanoe.
